questions.explanation: First, find out how many stickers each friend gets from Sarah: 24 stickers ÷ 3 friends = 8 stickers per friend. Then, add the stickers they already had: 8 stickers + 5 stickers = 13 stickers per friend.

options: The number of boxes will double
The number of boxes will be halved
The number of boxes will stay the same
questions.question: A factory packs 100 toys into boxes, with 10 toys in each box. If they double the number of toys per box to 20, how will the number of boxes change, assuming the total number of toys remains 100?
questions.explanation: Originally, 100 toys ÷ 10 toys/box = 10 boxes. If they pack 20 toys per box, then 100 toys ÷ 20 toys/box = 5 boxes. Doubling the number of items per box (divisor) halves the number of boxes needed (quotient), because multiplication and division are inverse operations.

questions.question: You have 36 pencils to organize. You can put them in groups of 4 or groups of 6. Which grouping will result in more groups, and how many more?
questions.explanation: If you make groups of 4: 36 ÷ 4 = 9 groups. If you make groups of 6: 36 ÷ 6 = 6 groups. Making groups of 4 results in 9 groups, which is 3 more groups than making groups of 6 (9 - 6 = 3).

title: 3rd Grade Mathematics - Chapter 4 - Number Line and Grid Strategies
description: Test covering Number Line and Grid Strategies concepts for 3rd Grade level students.
subject: Mathematics

questions.question: You are at 25 on a number line. If you jump forward 8 steps, what number will you land on?
questions.explanation: Starting at 25 and jumping forward 8 steps means you add 8. So, 25 + 8 = 33.

questions.question: A grasshopper is at 47 on a number line. It jumps backward 6 steps. What number does it land on?
questions.explanation: Jumping backward 6 steps means you subtract 6 from your starting number. So, 47 - 6 = 41.

questions.question: Imagine a number grid where moving down one row adds 10 to your number. If you are at 35 and move down one row, what number will you land on?
questions.explanation: On a number grid, moving down one row typically increases the number by 10. So, 35 + 10 = 45.

questions.question: A number line shows a jump starting at 50 and ending at 80. How big was this jump?
questions.explanation: To find the size of the jump, you subtract the starting number from the ending number: 80 - 50 = 30.

questions.question: A frog starts at 15 on a number line and jumps forward by 10 three times. What number will the frog land on?
questions.explanation: The frog starts at 15. After the first jump: 15 + 10 = 25. After the second jump: 25 + 10 = 35. After the third jump: 35 + 10 = 45.

questions.question: A grasshopper is at 72. It jumps backward by 10 two times. What number does it land on?
questions.explanation: The grasshopper starts at 72. First jump backward: 72 - 10 = 62. Second jump backward: 62 - 10 = 52.

questions.question: A child starts at 18 on a number line. They make a jump of +2, and then another jump of +5. What number do they reach in total?
questions.explanation: First, 18 + 2 = 20. Then, 20 + 5 = 25. The child reaches 25.

options: A. Start at 45, jump +20, then jump +8.
B. Start at 45, jump +30, then jump -2.
questions.question: You want to add 28 to 45. Which of these methods correctly uses jumps on a number line to reach the answer?
questions.explanation:
The sum of 45 + 28 is 73.
A. If you start at 45, jump +20 (to 65), then jump +8 (to 73). This is correct.
B. If you start at 45, jump +30 (to 75), then jump -2 (to 73). This is also correct. Both methods successfully reach 73.

options: A. Move down 2 rows, then move right 3 spaces.
B. Move right 3 spaces, then move up 2 rows.
C. Move down 3 rows, then move left 2 spaces.
D. Move up 2 rows, then move left 3 spaces.
questions.question: You are at 42 on a number grid (where moving down a row adds 10 and moving right one space adds 1). You want to add 23. Which jump sequence correctly finds the answer?
questions.explanation: To add 23 to 42, you can break 23 into 20 + 3. Moving down 2 rows adds 20 (10 for each row). Moving right 3 spaces adds 3 (1 for each space). So, 42 + 20 (down 2 rows) = 62. Then, 62 + 3 (right 3 spaces) = 65. The answer is 42 + 23 = 65.

questions.question: Sarah had 35 stickers. She got 15 more from her friend. Then, she used 7 stickers. If she used a number line to solve this, what would be her final number of stickers?
questions.explanation: First, Sarah had 35 stickers and got 15 more, so you add 15: 35 + 15 = 50 stickers. Then, she used 7 stickers, which means you subtract 7: 50 - 7 = 43 stickers. Her final number of stickers is 43.

title: 3rd Grade Mathematics - Chapter 4 - Solving Word Problems
description: Test covering Solving Word Problems concepts for 3rd Grade level students.
subject: Mathematics

questions.question: A shop sold 34 red balloons and 45 blue balloons. How many balloons were sold in total?
questions.explanation: To find the total number of balloons, you add the number of red balloons and blue balloons: 34 + 45 = 79.

questions.question: Sarah had 52 stickers. She gave 15 stickers to her friend. How many stickers does Sarah have left?
questions.explanation: To find out how many stickers Sarah has left, you subtract the stickers she gave away from the total she had: 52 - 15 = 37.

questions.question: There are 23 students in Class A and 18 students in Class B. How many more students are in Class A than Class B?
questions.explanation: To find out how many more students are in Class A, you subtract the number of students in Class B from Class A: 23 - 18 = 5.

questions.question: A baker made 28 chocolate cookies and 36 vanilla cookies. How many cookies did the baker make altogether?
questions.explanation: To find the total number of cookies, you add the chocolate cookies and vanilla cookies: 28 + 36 = 64.

questions.question: A park has 75 trees. 32 of them are oak trees, and the rest are pine trees. How many pine trees are in the park?
questions.explanation: To find the number of pine trees, you subtract the number of oak trees from the total number of trees: 75 - 32 = 43.

questions.question: Which word tells you to add numbers in a word problem?
questions.explanation: The word 'total' usually means you need to add all the numbers together to find the sum.

questions.question: If a word problem asks 'How many more?' or 'How many less?', what operation should you use?
questions.explanation: Questions like 'How many more?' or 'How many less?' ask for the difference between two numbers, which means you should subtract.

questions.question: Rohan had 45 marbles. His friend gave him 15 more marbles. Then, Rohan lost 10 marbles. How many marbles does Rohan have now?
questions.explanation: First, Rohan's marbles increased: 45 + 15 = 60 marbles. Then, he lost some: 60 - 10 = 50 marbles. So, Rohan has 50 marbles now.

questions.question: Maria collected 68 seashells, and Tom collected 53 seashells. They want to know who collected more and by how many. What is the correct way to find this out?
questions.explanation: To find out who collected more and by how many, you need to find the difference between the two numbers. You subtract the smaller number from the larger number: 68 - 53.

questions.question: A gardener planted 27 rose bushes and 35 tulip bulbs. He also bought 10 new gardening tools. How many plants did the gardener put in the ground in total?
questions.explanation: The question asks about the total number of *plants* in the ground. You need to add the rose bushes and tulip bulbs: 27 + 35 = 62. The gardening tools are extra information not needed to solve this specific question.

title: 3rd Grade Mathematics - Chapter 4 - Multi-Digit Addition and Subtraction
description: Test covering Multi-Digit Addition and Subtraction concepts for 3rd Grade level students.
subject: Mathematics

questions.question: What is the sum of 23 and 12?
questions.explanation: To find the sum of 23 and 12, add the ones digits: 3 + 2 = 5. Then add the tens digits: 2 + 1 = 3. So, 23 + 12 = 35.

questions.question: What is 33 minus 5?
questions.explanation: To subtract 5 from 33, you can count back 5 steps from 33: 32, 31, 30, 29, 28. So, 33 - 5 = 28.

questions.question: Add 25 and 36. What is the total?
questions.explanation: First, add the ones digits: 5 + 6 = 11. Write down 1 in the ones place and carry over 1 ten. Next, add the tens digits: 2 + 3 + (the carried 1) = 6. So, 25 + 36 = 61.

questions.question: Subtract 37 from 52. What is the difference?
questions.explanation: Start with the ones place: You cannot subtract 7 from 2, so you need to regroup. Take 1 ten from the 5 tens in 52, leaving 4 tens, and add it to the 2 ones, making 12 ones. Now, 12 - 7 = 5. In the tens place, subtract 3 from the remaining 4 tens: 4 - 3 = 1. So, 52 - 37 = 15.

questions.question: Nandini collected 85 apples and Chirag collected 67 apples. How many apples did they collect in total?
questions.explanation: First, add the ones digits: 5 + 7 = 12. Write down 2 in the ones place and carry over 1 ten. Next, add the tens digits: 8 + 6 + (the carried 1) = 15. So, 85 + 67 = 152 apples.

questions.question: Nani Maa put 100 vegetables in a box. If 65 of them were tomatoes, how many were other vegetables?
questions.explanation: To find the number of other vegetables, subtract the number of tomatoes from the total vegetables: 100 - 65. You can subtract 60 from 100 to get 40, then subtract 5 more to get 35. So, 100 - 65 = 35 other vegetables.

questions.question: What is 45 + 15 + 20?
questions.explanation: First, add 45 and 15: 45 + 15 = 60. Then, add 20 to that sum: 60 + 20 = 80. So, 45 + 15 + 20 = 80.

questions.question: Babli didi sold 34 books on Monday and 45 books on Tuesday. How many more books did she sell on Tuesday than on Monday?
questions.explanation: To find out how many more books were sold on Tuesday, subtract the number of books sold on Monday from the number sold on Tuesday: 45 - 34. Subtract the ones digits: 5 - 4 = 1. Subtract the tens digits: 4 - 3 = 1. So, she sold 11 more books on Tuesday.

options: A) Team Red scored 21 runs more than Team Blue.
B) Team Red scored 21 runs less than Team Blue.
C) Team Red scored 121 runs more than Team Blue.
D) Team Red scored 11 runs more than Team Blue.
questions.question: In a cricket match, Team Red scored 56 runs before lunch and 65 runs after lunch. Team Blue scored a total of 100 runs. Did Team Red score more or less than Team Blue, and by how much?
questions.explanation: First, find Team Red's total score: 56 + 65. Add the ones: 6 + 5 = 11 (write 1, carry 1). Add the tens: 5 + 6 + 1 (carried) = 12. So, Team Red scored 121 runs. Then, compare Team Red's score (121) to Team Blue's score (100). Team Red scored 121 - 100 = 21 runs more than Team Blue.

questions.question: You have 42 beads. How many more beads do you need to have a total of 75 beads?
questions.explanation: To find out how many more beads are needed, subtract the number of beads you have from the total number you want: 75 - 42. Subtract the ones digits: 5 - 2 = 3. Subtract the tens digits: 7 - 4 = 3. So, you need 33 more beads.

title: 3rd Grade Mathematics - Chapter 2 - Spatial Reasoning with 3D Shapes
description: Test covering Spatial Reasoning with 3D Shapes concepts for 3rd Grade level students.
subject: Mathematics

questions.question: A common object that looks like a soda can or a bottle without its lid is what 3D shape?
questions.explanation: Objects like soda cans have a round base and top, and a curved side, which are characteristics of a cylinder.

questions.question: How many flat faces does a cuboid have?
questions.explanation: A cuboid, like a rectangular box, has six flat faces.

questions.question: Which 3D shape has a pointed top and a circular flat base?
questions.explanation: A cone is identified by its single circular flat base and its side tapering to a point at the top.

questions.question: A perfect bouncy ball is an example of which 3D shape?
questions.explanation: A sphere is a perfectly round 3D object, like a ball.

options: A) On top of one book
C) In the middle of the two books
D) Far away from the books
questions.question: If a small box is placed *between* two larger books, where is the small box?
questions.explanation: The term 'between' means positioned in the space separating two other objects.

questions.question: What kind of 3D shape is also considered a special type of cuboid because all its faces are squares?
questions.explanation: A cube is a special type of cuboid where all six faces are identical squares.

questions.question: Which of these 3D shapes has only curved surfaces and no flat faces or edges?
questions.explanation: A sphere is completely round, meaning it has one continuous curved surface and no flat faces or straight edges.

questions.question: Imagine you are building a tower. You put a cuboid at the bottom, then a cube on top of the cuboid, and finally a cylinder on top of the cube. What shape is directly under the cylinder?
questions.explanation: The tower is built with the cuboid at the base, the cube on top of the cuboid, and the cylinder on top of the cube. Therefore, the cube is directly under the cylinder.

questions.question: Which of these 3D shapes can easily roll if placed on its side, but not if placed on its flat face?
questions.explanation: A cone has a curved side that allows it to roll when placed on its side. However, if placed on its flat circular base, it would not roll easily. A sphere rolls in any direction, and cubes/cuboids do not roll easily at all.

options: A) A larger cube or cuboid
questions.question: If you have many small cubes and you stack them perfectly to form a larger solid rectangular block, what 3D shape have you created?
questions.explanation: Stacking smaller cubes together, especially in a rectangular arrangement, will always result in a larger cube (if all sides are equal) or a cuboid (if sides are different lengths). Cubes and cuboids are rectangular prisms.

title: 3rd Grade Mathematics - Chapter 2 - Properties of 3D Shapes
description: Test covering Properties of 3D Shapes concepts for 3rd Grade level students.
subject: Mathematics

questions.question: A common object like a soda can or a bottle usually has the shape of a what?
questions.explanation: Cylinders have two flat circular faces and a curved side, just like many cans and bottles. They can roll on their curved side or stand upright on their flat faces.

questions.question: How many flat faces does a cube have?
questions.explanation: A cube is a 3D shape with 6 flat square faces. Think of a dice; each side you can land on is a face.

questions.question: Which 3D shape has no flat faces, no edges, and no corners?
questions.explanation: A sphere is perfectly round, like a ball, and does not have any flat parts, edges, or sharp corners.

questions.question: Which 3D shape has a pointed top and a flat circular base?
questions.explanation: A cone, like an ice cream cone, has a round flat bottom and comes to a single point at the top.

questions.question: A cube is a special kind of what other 3D shape?
questions.explanation: A cube is a special type of cuboid. The difference is that all the faces of a cube are squares, while a cuboid can have rectangular faces that are not squares.

questions.question: Which of these shapes has only flat faces and no curved surfaces?
questions.explanation: A cuboid has six flat rectangular faces. Spheres, cylinders, and cones all have curved surfaces as part of their shape.

questions.question: Which 3D shape has some flat faces and also a curved surface?
questions.explanation: A cylinder has two flat circular faces (the top and bottom) and one curved surface around its side. A cone also has one flat face and one curved surface.

questions.question: Imagine you have a cube, a sphere, a cone, and a cuboid. Which one would be the easiest to roll across a smooth floor?
questions.explanation: A sphere is perfectly round and has no flat surfaces or edges, making it the easiest to roll smoothly without stopping.

questions.question: I am a 3D shape. I have exactly 6 flat faces. Not all of my faces are squares, but I have 12 straight edges and 8 corners. What shape am I?
questions.explanation: A cuboid has 6 flat rectangular faces, 12 straight edges, and 8 corners. A cube also has these numbers but all its faces are squares, which the question says are not all squares.

questions.question: If you want to build a very tall and stable tower by stacking identical 3D shapes, which shape would generally be the best choice to stack on top of each other?
questions.explanation: Shapes with large, flat surfaces like cubes are the most stable for stacking to build a tall tower because they provide a strong, even base for the next shape.

title: 3rd Grade Mathematics - Chapter 2 - Identifying 3D Shapes
description: Test covering Identifying 3D Shapes concepts for 3rd Grade level students.
subject: Mathematics

questions.question: A 3D shape that has a curved surface and two flat, circular ends is called a:
questions.explanation: A cylinder has a curved side and two flat, circular faces at the top and bottom. Think of a can of soup!

questions.question: Which 3D shape has six faces that are all squares?
questions.explanation: A cube is a special 3D shape where all six of its flat faces are identical squares. Think of a dice!

questions.question: A shape that is perfectly round like a ball and has no flat faces or straight edges is a:
questions.explanation: A sphere is a perfectly round 3D shape, like a globe or a soccer ball. It can roll in any direction.

questions.question: How many straight edges does a cube have?
questions.explanation: A cube has 12 straight edges where its faces meet. You can count them on a dice or a building block.

questions.question: Which of these 3D shapes has exactly one flat circular face and one pointed top?
questions.explanation: A cone has one flat, circular base and narrows to a single point at the top. Think of an ice cream cone!

questions.question: A cuboid has rectangular faces. How many faces does a cuboid have in total?
questions.explanation: Just like a cube, a cuboid has 6 flat faces. These faces can be different-sized rectangles. Think of a shoebox.

questions.question: Which 3D shape is like a box that can have faces that are different sized rectangles?
questions.explanation: A cuboid has 6 flat faces, and unlike a cube, its rectangular faces can be different sizes. For example, a brick or a book.

questions.question: Which of these groups contains only 3D shapes that can roll easily?
questions.explanation: Cylinders, spheres, and cones all have curved surfaces which allow them to roll easily. Cubes and cuboids only have flat surfaces, so they slide or stack.

options: It has more faces than a cuboid.
All its faces are squares and are the same size.
questions.question: A cube is called a 'special type of cuboid'. What makes a cube special?
questions.explanation: Both cubes and cuboids have 6 faces. What makes a cube special is that all of its 6 faces are identical squares, whereas a regular cuboid can have different-sized rectangular faces.

questions.question: Imagine you are stacking 3D shapes to build a tall structure. Which shape would be the most difficult to place at the very bottom as a stable base, if you only had one of each shape?
questions.explanation: A sphere is round and has no flat base, making it very unstable and difficult to stack other shapes on top of it. Cubes, cylinders, and cuboids all have flat bases for stacking.

title: Grade 4 Math - Metric Conversions and Practical Applications
description: Test covering metric conversions, estimation, and real-world problem solving from Grade 4 Unit 1
subject: Mathematics

questions.question: Convert 5 meters to centimeters.
questions.explanation: 1 meter = 100 centimeters, so 5 meters = 5 × 100 = 500 centimeters.

questions.question: Convert 3 kilograms to grams.
questions.explanation: 1 kilogram = 1,000 grams, so 3 kilograms = 3 × 1,000 = 3,000 grams.

questions.question: A rope is 2 meters long. How many centimeters is this?
questions.explanation: 2 meters = 2 × 100 = 200 centimeters.

questions.question: Which is heavier: 2 kilograms or 1,500 grams?
questions.explanation: 2 kilograms = 2,000 grams, which is heavier than 1,500 grams.

questions.question: A table is 150 centimeters long. How many meters is this?
questions.explanation: 150 centimeters = 150 ÷ 100 = 1.5 meters.

questions.question: Estimate the length of a classroom that is 8 meters long in centimeters.
questions.explanation: 8 meters ≈ 8 × 100 = 800 centimeters.

questions.question: A bag of rice weighs 2,500 grams. How many kilograms is this?
Which measurement is reasonable for the height of a door?
questions.explanation: A door is typically about 200 centimeters (2 meters) tall.

questions.question: Convert 4.5 meters to centimeters.
questions.explanation: 4.5 meters = 4.5 × 100 = 450 centimeters.

questions.question: A pencil weighs 15 grams. How many pencils would weigh 1 kilogram?
questions.explanation: 1 kilogram = 1,000 grams. 1,000 ÷ 15 ≈ 67 pencils.

title: Grade 4 Math - Arithmetic Operations and Problem Solving
description: Advanced test focusing on addition, subtraction, multiplicative comparisons, and word problems from Grade 4 Unit 1
subject: Mathematics

questions.question: What is 48 ÷ 6?
questions.explanation: 48 ÷ 6 = 8, which means 48 is 6 times as much as 8.

questions.question: If 48 is 6 times as much as 8, which equation represents this relationship?
questions.explanation: 48 ÷ 6 = 8 represents the multiplicative comparison '48 is 6 times as much as 8'.

questions.question: Add: 234,567 + 123,456
questions.explanation: 234,567 + 123,456 = 358,023. Add each place value column from right to left.

questions.question: Subtract: 456,789 - 123,456
questions.explanation: 456,789 - 123,456 = 333,333. Subtract each place value column from right to left.

questions.question: Sarah has 24 stickers. Tom has 3 times as many stickers as Sarah. How many stickers does Tom have?
questions.explanation: Tom has 3 times as many as Sarah: 24 × 3 = 72 stickers.

questions.question: A school has 1,250 students. If 456 students are in 4th grade, how many students are in other grades?
questions.explanation: Students in other grades: 1,250 - 456 = 794 students.

questions.question: Estimate the sum: 2,345 + 1,678
questions.explanation: 2,345 + 1,678 ≈ 2,000 + 2,000 = 4,000 (rounded to nearest thousand).

options: One bar with 36, four bars with 9 each
Four bars with 36 each, one bar with 9
One bar with 9, four bars with 9 each
One bar with 36, one bar with 9
questions.question: Which tape diagram correctly shows '36 is 4 times as much as 9'?
questions.explanation: The tape diagram should show one bar representing 36 and four equal bars representing 9 each, since 36 = 4 × 9.

questions.question: A bookstore has 2,500 books. They sold 1,234 books this month. How many books remain?
questions.explanation: Books remaining: 2,500 - 1,234 = 1,266 books.

questions.question: If a box contains 8 rows of 6 items each, how many items are in the box?
questions.explanation: Total items: 8 rows × 6 items per row = 48 items.

title: Grade 4 Math - Place Value and Number Forms
description: Comprehensive test covering place value understanding, number forms, and rounding concepts from Grade 4 Unit 1
subject: Mathematics

questions.question: In the number 1,334, how many times larger is the 3 in the hundreds place compared to the 3 in the tens place?
questions.explanation: In place value, each position is 10 times larger than the position to its right. So the hundreds place is 10 times larger than the tens place.

questions.question: What is the word form of 42,910?
questions.explanation: 42,910 in word form is 'Forty-two thousand, nine hundred ten'.

questions.question: Which number shows 9,000 is 10 times larger than 900?
questions.explanation: 900 × 10 = 9,000 shows that 9,000 is 10 times larger than 900.

questions.question: What is the expanded form of 5,847?
questions.explanation: 5,847 in expanded form is 5,000 + 800 + 40 + 7.

questions.question: Round 23,456 to the nearest thousand.
questions.explanation: 23,456 rounded to the nearest thousand is 23,000 because the hundreds digit (4) is less than 5.

questions.question: Round 67,891 to the nearest ten thousand.
questions.explanation: 67,891 rounded to the nearest ten thousand is 70,000 because the thousands digit (7) is 5 or greater.

questions.question: What is the standard form of 'Three thousand, four hundred fifty-six'?
questions.explanation: 'Three thousand, four hundred fifty-six' in standard form is 3,456.

questions.question: In the number 45,678, what is the value of the digit 6?
questions.explanation: The digit 6 in 45,678 is in the hundreds place, so its value is 600.

questions.question: Which comparison is correct?
questions.explanation: 123,456 < 123,465 because 456 < 465 in the ones, tens, and hundreds places.

questions.question: Round 89,999 to the nearest hundred thousand.
questions.explanation: 89,999 rounded to the nearest hundred thousand is 100,000 because the ten thousands digit (8) is 5 or greater.

title: US - Math shapes test
description: Shapes - perimeter related
subject: Mathematics

questions.text: A rectangle has a length of 8 cm and a width of 5 cam . What is the perimeter?
A square has a side of 6 m . What is its perimeter ?
A triangle has sides of 4 cm , 7 cm and 9 cm
